JRN108.name: The World of Media
JRN108.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
JRN108.description: Introduction to the wide array of the journalism and media industries. Examination of established to emerging media and their content and audiences, content dissemination, policy and management decision-making, theory, history, development and current structure of the media. Role and impact of media on society and vice-versa, careers, law and ethics, media literacy and diversity.

JRN200.name: Writing and Reporting News
JRN200.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
JRN200.description: Basic reporting and writing skills. Storytelling with news judgment, information gathering, readability and ethics. News styles and structure in alternative delivery methods. Independent sources and interviewing techniques in a lab setting. Writing news across platforms. AP style.
JRN200.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

JRN203.name: Visual Storytelling
JRN203.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
JRN203.description: Explorations of visual storytelling techniques and technologies, including photography, audio, video, information graphics, alternative story forms and social media.
JRN203.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the College of Communication Arts and Sciences.

JRN206.name: Video Storytelling with Phones
JRN206.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
JRN206.description: Fundamentals of video storytelling using phone cameras. Basics of shooting and editing video. Video aesthetics. Natural sound. Audio and microphones. Interviewing. Journalism news gathering and ethics.

JRN211.name: Documentary History and Theory
JRN211.description: Documentary history and theory form its origins to the present.
JRN211.restrictions: Open to students in the School of Journalism or in the Department of Media and Information or in the Department of Writing, Rhetoric and American Cultures or in the Documentary Studies Specialization or in the Film Studies major.

JRN212.name: 2D Animation Storytelling
JRN212.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
JRN212.description: Theory and production practice of creating 2D animation in cultural storytelling and education.

JRN213.name: Animation, Comics, Culture and Graphic Novels in Media
JRN213.description: Study of the development and relevance of comics and graphic novels from around the world to cultural and historical issues and events. Creation of digital and interactive comics to market work for transmedia publication. Special emphasis is put on creating short comics around news issues and events, educational and instructional comics, interactive, animated and experimental comic styles.

JRN218.name: Sports in Contemporary Media
JRN218.description: Introduction to today’s media coverage of sports, including college and professional major and Olympic sports. Survey of development of traditional and new media reporting. Legal, and ethical issues, including contracts and copyrights of sports media.
JRN218.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

JRN265.name: International Journalism and Media
JRN265.description: Survey of journalism processes and media systems around the world. Contemporary issues in international journalism. Press theory and effects on press freedom and media independence. Foreign correspondence reporting.

JRN300.name: Multimedia Writing and Reporting (W)
JRN300.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
JRN300.description: Powerful writing combined with visual communication and social media for multimedia reporting. Developing story ideas and interview techniques for covering public affairs and communities. Stories are published online.
JRN300.prerequisite: (JRN 200 and (JRN 203 or concurrently)) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

JRN303.name: On-Air Announcing, Interviewing and Hosting
JRN303.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
JRN303.description: Hands-on experience to be comfortable in front of a camera and microphone in a live setting doing interviews or presenting information. Effective host and anchor techniques across various digital platforms for all different styles of programming, including news, sports and entertainment.

JRN305.name: Editing for Print and Digital
JRN305.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
JRN305.description: Editing for accuracy, brevity and maximum impact to improve one's own writing and that of others for today's media and publication.

JRN306.name: Introduction to Radio, Podcasting and TV News
JRN306.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
JRN306.description: Fundamentals of audio storytelling. Introduction to broadcast style writing; scripting for radio news and podcasting; voice tone and cadence. Exposure to professional cameras for video stories.
JRN306.prerequisite: (JRN 300 or concurrently) and JRN 206 or approval of department

JRN310.name: Photojournalism
JRN310.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
JRN310.description: Photography storytelling by learning the principles and ethics of successful visual communication, camera operation and software editing.
JRN310.prerequisite: JRN 203 or JRN 483 or approval of school
JRN310.restrictions: Open to students in the School of Journalism.

JRN311.name: Introduction to Documentary Production
JRN311.description: Introduction to documentary production using accessible and affordable digital technology.
JRN311.restrictions: Open to students in the Documentary Production Minor.

JRN312.name: Stop Motion Animation Storytelling
JRN312.description: Creation of digital stop motion animation sequences to tell a narrative story or recreate a historical or current world event. History of stop motion animation, character rigging and kinetics, storyboarding, plot and sequence development.

JRN313.name: Political Cartoons
JRN313.description: Survey and critique of political cartoons from around the world from ancient Egypt through today. Impact the cartoons can have on society as well as the techniques to research, create, and market political cartoons.

JRN317.name: Sports Journalism
JRN317.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
JRN317.description: Introduction to the specialized field of sports journalism. Reporting on high school, college, Olympic, and professional major sports. Interaction with sports journalists from various media; writing and producing sports stories in multi-media formats. Ethical decision-making.

JRN325.name: Journalism History
JRN325.description: Development of journalism in the United States from colonial to the present; examination of evolving written, aural, visual and multimedia forms and relevant media technology. Journalism's history has impacted and influenced U.S. history in interesting ways.

JRN336.name: Designing for Media
JRN336.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
JRN336.description: Creating and composing visual communication design for digital and print publications. Theory and practice in typography, visual editing, alternative story forms, hierarchy and use of color.

JRN338.name: Information Graphics
JRN338.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
JRN338.description: Information graphics, or infographics, are graphic visual representations of information used to make information clearer and more understandable, accessible and engaging. Theory, application and production of print, animated and interactive information graphics using visual tools, like maps, charts, diagrams and illustrations.

JRN345.name: Images and Messages
JRN345.description: Visual communication through analytical, historical and critical views. Role and effects of imagery in storytelling, news and documentary presentations. Ethics of visual messages. Impact of technology on visual journalism. Aesthetics of imagery and cultural belief systems associated with the medium of photography.

JRN365.name: International News and Government Dynamics
JRN365.semester: Spring of every year, Summer of every year
JRN365.description: Explores the importance of journalism in the process of building governments in different countries. Compares features of global media and coverage in international contexts. Regions rotate each year

JRN372.name: Environment, Science and Health Journalism Special Topics
JRN372.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
JRN372.description: Analyze and understand the context of environment, science and health events and issues for news coverage.

JRN375.name: International Journalism and Media
JRN375.description: Survey of media and journalism news systems around the world. Contemporary issues in international journalism. Press theory and effects on press freedom and media independence. Foreign correspondence reporting.

JRN402.name: Public Relations Topics in Journalism
JRN402.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
JRN402.description: Current and rotating topics related to the practice of public relations.
JRN402.restrictions: Open to students in the Journalism Major or in the Public Relations Minor. A student may earn a maximum of 6 credits in any or all enrollments in ADV 402, COM 402, JRN 402.

JRN403.name: TV News
JRN403.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
JRN403.description: Creating video news stories for TV and digital platforms. Entry-level producing and anchoring for regular short newscasts. Introduction to broadcast style writing for video. Multi-media reporting for TV news broadcasts.
JRN403.restrictions: Open to students in the School of Journalism.

JRN406.name: Advanced TV News Storytelling and Producing
JRN406.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
JRN406.description: Announcing, reporting, and producing newscasts for TV and digital platforms, honing skills in video, audio, broadcast writing, TV news storytelling, interviewing and reporting. Advanced producing techniques, social media strategies for journalism and create a professional portfolio for future employers.

JRN407.name: Advanced Reporting
JRN407.description: Developing indepth news stories, using traditional and innovative investigative reporting skills and techniques. Finding and analyzing databases. Following up with interviews and sources. Visualizing data. Employing the Freedom of Information Act to obtain public/government records.

JRN409.name: Advising Student Publications
JRN409.semester: Spring of every year, Summer of every year
JRN409.description: Themes and issues to oversee successful student publications such as staff organization and policies, finance, law, photography, design and role of the student press.
JRN409.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing requirement
JRN409.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students and approval of school.

JRN410.name: Advanced Photojournalism: Documentary
JRN410.description: Advanced photographic storytelling and editing for media. Social documentary/long-form photography and layout. Technical and aesthetic skills. Studio and strobe lighting. Build a portfolio.

JRN411.name: Collaborative Documentary Design and Production (W)
JRN411.description: Design and development of documentaries in a team setting using video and audio, still photography, web design, and print media. Participation in a production cycle including idea generation, research, design, production, and distribution.
JRN411.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
JRN411.restrictions: Open to students in the Documentary Production Minor.

JRN413.name: 3D Animation Storytelling
JRN413.description: Character development in regard to culture and story. Advanced relationship of physics between character and the environment through micro facial expressions, body language of walk and gesture.

JRN416.name: Sports Multimedia Content Management
JRN416.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
JRN416.description: Packaging, editing, and making ethical decisions in sports newsrooms. Making strong content choices, from SEO to visual to broadcast to print. Editing, content choice, and coverage on ethical/diversity levels.

JRN417.name: Sports Reporting
JRN417.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
JRN417.description: Introduction to specialized field of sports journalism; reporting on high school, college and professional major sports and Olympic sports. Interaction with sports journalists from various media; writing and producing sports stories in multi-media formats.

JRN418.name: Advanced Sports Reporting
JRN418.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
JRN418.description: Upper-level exploration of issues in sports journalism and directed professional work experiences at outlets such as WKAR's Current Sports (radio/TV/web) and FOX Sports.

JRN420.name: Capital News Service
JRN420.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
JRN420.description: Supervised professional experience in covering Michigan politics and state government as correspondents for selected media. Student work and bylines appear in professional print and online media, preparing them for the industry.

JRN430.name: News Media Law and Ethics
JRN430.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
JRN430.description: Legal and ethical nature of news gathering and dissemination. Moral issues in gathering and reporting news. First amendment principles of press freedom. Libel, invasion of privacy, prior restraint, access to information. Objectivity, sensitivity, covering victims, source relations.

JRN432.name: Magazine, Feature and Freelance Writing
JRN432.description: Storytelling for long-form narratives for magazines and other media outlets. Delve into the human interest angle when developing stories to educate and/or entertain. Learn how to pitch stories to get published.

JRN436.name: Design for Web and Mobile Devices
JRN436.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
JRN436.description: Theory and practice in designing online publications. Content gathering including text, digital images and multimedia elements. Emphasis on information, interaction and presentation design. Includes coding such as HTML and CSS.

JRN438.name: Advanced Information Graphics
JRN438.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
JRN438.description: Creating visual storytelling with advanced techniques and technologies for communicating information online and across media. Using graphics, animation and other methods to represent data simply to various audiences.

JRN450.name: Media Innovation and Entrepreneurship
JRN450.description: Developing and marketing innovations in journalism media that have the potential for commercial enterprise. Building blocks of entrepreneurship to know how to test markets, prototype, and develop audiences.
JRN450.restrictions: Open to students in the College of Communication Arts and Sciences.

JRN465.name: International Reporting
JRN465.description: Writing and reporting significant and innovative stories on international and global affairs. Understanding varying degrees of press freedom in different cultures, and reporting with a sensitivity to diversity and cultural contexts.
JRN465.prerequisite: JRN 265 and JRN 300 or approval of school

JRN472.name: Environmental, Science and Health Reporting
JRN472.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
JRN472.description: Investigative reporting on environment, science and health. Text, video, audio stories published on GreatLakesEcho.org and other venues. Analyzing environment, science and health events and issues for news coverage.

JRN475.name: International News and Government Dynamics
JRN475.description: Comparative features of global media and coverage within regional contexts that rotate each year

JRN483.name: Photo Communication in Europe
JRN483.description: Study abroad. Introduction to contemporary photographers including those working in documentary, photojournalism, advertising and art. Visits to historical collections of photography, museums, galleries, and studios. Structured travel to historical and cultural sites. Practical experience in digital photography including shooting, editing, storytelling and packaging.

JRN484.name: Sports Journalism Education Abroad
JRN484.description: Examine European sporting cultures (ancient and modern) in Paris and Rome. Study how sports journalism operates in both cities through experiential learning by attending tours, guest lectures, experiencing live sporting events and seeing sports journalism in action.

JRN485.name: Environmental Communication Education Abroad
JRN485.description: Local environmental problems and the ways in which they are connected to political, economic, social, and ecosystemic dynamics at a global scale. Explore the ways in which diverse stakeholders involved in environmental decision-making use communication strategies to achieve their goals and objectives.

JRN486.name: British and Irish Mass Media Education Abroad
JRN486.description: Examine the rapidly changing world of media and communication in London, Scotland, Ireland, and Wales. Themes studied are traditional and digital media, marketing and advertising, journalism, broadcasting and public relations.

JRN487.name: Creative Journey Education Abroad
JRN487.description: Visual communication for the transfer of ideas, knowledge and data. Visual tools including videos, infographics, color, typography, and photography.

JRN490.name: Independent Study
JRN490.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
JRN490.description: Supervised individual study in an area of journalism.

JRN492.name: Journalism Special Topics
JRN492.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
JRN492.description: Various issues, skills or themes relating to journalism.

JRN493.name: Journalism Professional Field Experience
JRN493.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
JRN493.description: Supervised field experience at a professional media organization. Media related issues.
JRN493.restrictions: Open to students in the Journalism Major. Approval of school; application required.

JRN800.name: Multiple Media Reporting I
JRN800.description: Development and practice of professional news judgment, writing, ethics, and skills across media platforms, such as print, online, audio, and video storytelling.

JRN801.name: Multiple Media Reporting II
JRN801.description: Investigative and in-depth project reporting across media platforms. Use of databases, documents, financial data, survey data and geographic information systems.

JRN803.name: Introduction to Quantitative Research Methods
JRN803.semester: Fall of every year, Summer of every year
JRN803.description: Introduction to quantitative social science research methods and applied analyses for understanding research reports and developing graduate level research projects.

JRN810.name: Visual Journalism
JRN810.description: Historical, theoretical, conceptual, ethical and technological approaches to the creation, processing and dissemination of visual information in journalism, documentary film, public relations and advertising. Explores both U.S. and international case studies.

JRN815.name: Media, Society and Theory
JRN815.description: Roles, impacts, organization, and performance of the news media in society.

JRN816.name: Applied Research Methods in Journalism
JRN816.description: Exposure to qualitative and quantitative methods of research for journalism. Methods include surveys, content analysis, focus groups, participant observation, historical, visual and document research.

JRN820.name: Capital News Service
JRN820.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
JRN820.description: Supervised professional experience in covering politics and state government as correspondents for selected media. Student work appears in professional print and online media.
JRN820.restrictions: Open to master's students in the College of Communication Arts and Sciences or in the School of Journalism or in the Journalism Major or approval of school.

JRN821.name: Social Media News and Information
JRN821.description: New technologies relevant to journalism. Assessing impact on the field. Use of these technologies in their work.

JRN872.name: Environment, Science and Health Reporting Topics
JRN872.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
JRN872.description: Resources and practical experience in reporting and writing about environment, science and health topics.

JRN873.name: Environment, Science and Health Journalism Seminar
JRN873.description: Issues in environmental, science and health journalism.

JRN875.name: Global Affairs Reporting
JRN875.description: Techniques and challenges in covering international events and issues such as economics, security, disasters, and public policy. Understanding international press systems, rights and constraints.

JRN887.name: Journalism Study Abroad Topics
JRN887.description: Topics vary. Blend of lectures, visits to media organizations, and fieldwork.
JRN887.restrictions: Open to graduate students. Approval of school.

JRN890.name: Independent Study
JRN890.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
JRN890.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the School of Journalism. Approval of school.

JRN892.name: Journalism Special Topics
JRN892.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year

JRN896.name: Journalism Professional Project
JRN896.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
JRN896.description: Individualized research, writing and production of in-depth journalism projects.
JRN896.restrictions: Open to master's students in the Journalism major. Approval of school.

JRN899.name: Master's Thesis Research
JRN899.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
JRN899.restrictions: Open to master's students in the Journalism major. Approval of school.

JRN900.name: Theory Building in Media and Information Studies
JRN900.description: Concepts and issues relating explanation, scientific inquiry, theory building and applications to interdisciplinary studies in media and information.

JRN916.name: Qualitative Research Methods
JRN916.description: Qualitative research in mass and specialized communication systems. Topics include documentary, bibliographic, case study and participant observation methods.
JRN916.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the College of Communication Arts and Sciences.

JRN921.name: Theories of Media and Information
JRN921.description: Overview of the relations between information theory, communication theory, and media theory, and an understanding of how these theories have evolved over time and which competing approaches coexist.
JRN921.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the College of Communication Arts and Sciences or approval of college.

JRN960.name: Media and Technology
JRN960.description: Theoretical frameworks concerning media and communication processes, and their interactions with technology. Social, organizational, critical, and economic perspectives.
JRN960.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the Communication Major or in the Media and Information Studies Major or approval of department.

JRN975.name: Introductory Methods
JRN975.description: A survey of qualitative and quantitative research design including validity and reliability, hypothesis formation, sampling, ethics, survey, experimental, ethnographic, observational and mixed methods.

JRN985.name: Advanced Quantitative Analysis for Media
JRN985.description: Multivariate research methods for media and information studies research.

JRN990.name: Independent Study
JRN990.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
JRN990.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the College of Communication Arts and Sciences or approval of college.

JRN991.name: Ways of Knowing
JRN991.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
JRN991.description: Ways humans acquire, convey, organize and shape knowledge and information, and are shaped and influenced by it. Neurological, psychological linguistic, philosophical, cultural, and logical dimensions of human knowledge.
JRN991.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the College of Communication Arts and Sciences or approval of college.

JRN992.name: Doctoral Seminar
JRN992.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
JRN992.description: Topics on theoretical and research issues in communication and mass media.
JRN992.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the College of Communication Arts and Sciences or approval of college.

JRN993.name: Research Practicum in Information and Media
JRN993.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
JRN993.description: Directed research collaboration with a faculty member or a team of students/faculty.
JRN993.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the College of Communication Arts and Sciences or approval of college.
